checklist: 3. RUN: mix bundles.track init maestro <branch> bootstrap
4. CHECK task section for your assignment
5. IF task unclear: Ask user BEFORE starting
common_mistakes: Skipping bundles.track init (YOU JUST DID THIS)
Not reading the task section (scroll down to 'task' key)
Jumping straight to browser_eval instead of reading code
Trying to coordinate tasks meant for other agents
Forgetting to log guideline refs with bundles.track ref
START_HERE.purpose: ONE IN THREE AGENTS GET LOST AT STARTUP. Follow this checklist BEFORE doing anything else.
tools_available: mix maestro.task.read TASK_ID - Read any task
mix maestro.task.update TASK_ID status VALUE - Update task
mix bundles.track ref GUIDELINE_ID 'what you did' - Log usage
mix bundles.track summary - End session logging
mix startup.build - Regenerate this file (at end)

anti_patterns: Trying to read agents/* files (they're symlinked, causes confusion)
Trying to memorize everything before starting
Loading project READMEs you're not working with

content.description: Essential startup docs only - load other bundles on-demand

source_files.AGENTS_SYMLINK.md:
# Accessing the Agents Directory

## The Setup

Every project has a symlink to the shared agents directory:

```bash
./agents -> ~/dev/agents
```

This means all projects share the same knowledge base!

## How to Access It

### ‚ùå WRONG - Will fail with security error:
```elixir
read_project_file("agents/docs/maestro/AGENTS.md")
```

**Error:** "The path is invalid or not relative to the project root"

**Why:** `read_project_file` tool has security restrictions against symlinks

### ‚úÖ CORRECT - Use shell_eval:
```elixir
shell_eval("cat agents/docs/maestro/AGENTS.md")
shell_eval("ls agents/docs/")
shell_eval("find agents -name '*.md'")
```

**Why:** Shell commands follow symlinks naturally

## Common Pattern

Every new agent tries `read_project_file` first, fails, then either:
1. **Figures out shell_eval works** (rare)
2. **Works around by creating files in /tmp then copying** (common)
3. **Assumes they can't access it at all** (most common)

## The Solution

**Add to startup.json critical_knowledge:**
```json
"agents_directory": "Use shell_eval to read agents/ symlink (read_project_file won't work due to security)"
```

## Directory Structure

```
./agents/              # Symlink to ~/dev/agents
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bundles/          # Pre-built JSON bundles (bootstrap, models, ui, tools, maestro, guides)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/             # Organized documentation
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bootstrap/    # Core patterns (Elixir, Phoenix, Ash, UI)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ models/       # Data layer patterns
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ui/           # View/controller patterns
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tools/        # Development tools
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ maestro/      # Coordination patterns (YOU ARE HERE)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ guides/       # General learnings
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ logs/             # Session logs (maestro/, sessions/)
```

## Why This Matters

1. **Shared Knowledge**: All projects access same learning base
2. **Version Control**: Agents directory is git-tracked independently
3. **Bundle System**: Maestro builds bundles from docs/ for efficient agent startup
4. **No Duplication**: One source of truth, symlinked everywhere

## For Future Agents

When you need to read agent documentation:
- **DO**: `shell_eval("cat agents/docs/category/FILE.md")`
- **DON'T**: `read_project_file("agents/docs/category/FILE.md")`

The symlink is there. Use it via shell.
source_files.AGENT_OPERATIONS_PATTERNS.md:
# AGENT_OPERATIONS Patterns

Core patterns and learnings for agent operations.

---


## 2025-10-30
- Agents report state via mix session.capacity (token usage) and mix bundles.track (what they used) - Maestro uses this to course-correct
- Write completion notes BEFORE marking task done - document first, status second
- Use Ash API for all task updates, never browser manipulation
- Log sessions consistently - agents often forget but it's crucial for learning

- Always format task description field when running a task
source_files.CRITICAL_10.md:
# CRITICAL 10 - Start Here

**These 10 rules prevent 90% of agent failures. Read these FIRST.**

## 1. STOP - Read Before Doing
**Problem:** Agents jump to implementation, waste 80% of tokens
**Action:** Read workflow, check existing tools, consult docs FIRST
**Example:** This session - jumped in, wasted 30% before following workflow

## 2. Follow the Workflow
**In startup.json:**
1. Read START_HERE checklist
2. Run `mix bundles.track init`
3. Check task section
4. Load relevant docs
5. Do work + log refs
6. End with bundles.track summary

## 3. Use Existing Tools (Don't Guess)
**Problem:** Agents use browser_eval when programmatic tools exist
**Check these FIRST:**
- `mix maestro.task.*` - Task operations
- `mix bundles.*` - Bundle operations  
- Ash API - Data updates (Resource.by_id!, .update, .create)
**Never:** Browser manipulation for data, SQL bypassing Ash

## 4. Read USAGE_RULES.md Before Building
**Location:** Project root - USAGE_RULES.md
**Contains:** Ash patterns, Phoenix, Ecto, LiveView, Elixir
**When:** ANY time you're about to write code using these
**Example:** KNOWLEDGE_WASTE_ANALYSIS shows 85% waste from not reading

## 5. Log What You Use
**Command:** `mix bundles.track ref GUIDELINE_ID "what you did"`
**Why:** System learns what's actually useful
**Currently:** Agents use 1% of rules, we don't know which 1%

## 6. Context = Check Your Task Assignment
**Problem:** Agents work on wrong tasks, wrong projects
**Check:**
- Is this task assigned to ME (current_task.json)?
- Or to another agent/project?
**Action:** If unclear, ASK before starting

## 7. Idempotent Tasks - Fix and Re-run
**Pattern:** Script fails? Fix the script, run it again
**Tools:** mix tasks in maestro_tool/lib/mix/tasks/
**Don't:** Work around broken scripts with manual commands
**Do:** Fix startup.build.ex, then run `mix startup.build`

## 8. Document BEFORE Status Change
**Order:**
1. Write completion notes (what was done, how it works, files changed)
2. THEN update status to :done
**Why:** If you mark done first, notes never get written

## 9. Ask When Uncertain
**If unclear:**
- Task requirements
- Multiple approaches possible
- Unknown existing patterns
**Then:** Ask user BEFORE implementing
**Don't:** Guess and waste tokens on wrong approach

## 10. Verify Programmatically First
**Priority:**
1. Ash queries (Maestro.Task.by_id!)
2. SQL queries (execute_sql_query)
3. Mix test
4. Shell commands
5. LAST RESORT: browser_eval
**Why:** Browser is slow, expensive, fragile

---

## Meta-Rule: Training Loop

**When you make a mistake:**
1. Identify the root cause
2. Find/create the tool to prevent it
3. Update guidelines
4. Run the tool to fix it
5. Document in CRITICAL_10

**This session's example:**
- Mistake: Skipped workflow, got lost
- Root cause: No visible checklist in startup.json
- Fix: Added START_HERE section to startup.build.ex
- Ran: mix startup.build
- Now: All future agents see it

---

**If you only remember 3 things:**
1. **STOP** - Read workflow/docs before doing
2. **USE TOOLS** - Check mix tasks, USAGE_RULES.md, existing code
3. **LOG** - Track what you actually use (bundles.track ref)
source_files.GUIDELINES.md:
# Agent Guidelines - Core Essentials

**The absolute minimum every agent must know.**

## Session Lifecycle

**Startup**: `mix session.startup`  
**Task completion**: `mix agent.task.response`  
**End session**: `mix bundles.track summary`

**Maestro assigns tasks**: `mix maestro.task.request TASK_ID PROJECT_PATH`

## Critical Rules

### Stop and Read First

**The Universal Pattern:**
1. **Stop** - Don't guess, don't jump to implementation
2. **Read relevant documentation** - Find the right guide/pattern
3. **Use the documented tool** - Apply what you just read

**Anti-patterns:**
- ‚ùå Using browser_eval when programmatic access exists
- ‚ùå Building infrastructure before reading what exists
- ‚ùå Trying solutions without consulting documentation
- ‚ùå Verifying in browser when you can query/test directly

**Why:** 
- Browser is slow and expensive
- Documentation already exists
- Proper tools are faster and more reliable

**Example from WHAT_WENT_WRONG:**
- Task needs data update
- ‚ùå Try browser_eval ‚Üí Fail ‚Üí Waste 10+ tool calls
- ‚úÖ Read USAGE_RULES.md Ash section ‚Üí Use `Resource.update()` ‚Üí Done in 5 lines

**The Math:**
- Session efficiency when reading first: ~80%
- Session efficiency when guessing: ~20%

### Use Ash for Data

```elixir
# Read
resource = MyApp.Resource.by_id!(id)

# Update
{:ok, updated} = MyApp.Resource.update(resource, %{field: value})

# Create  
{:ok, new} = MyApp.Resource.create(%{field: value})
```

Never bypass with: direct SQL, Ecto, LiveView assigns, browser manipulation.

### Log Sessions

```bash
mix bundles.track init <project> <branch> <bundle>
mix bundles.track ref <guideline_id> "what you did"
mix bundles.track summary
```

## Communication

- **Ask when:** Requirements unclear, multiple approaches, unknown logic
- **Proceed when:** Task clear, work verifiable

## Workflow

1. Read task
2. Read relevant docs (STOP and READ!)
3. Plan (share if complex)
4. Make changes using documented tools
5. Test programmatically
6. Report

## Testing

Before marking complete:
- Run: `mix test`
- Check logs
- Handle edge cases
- Use programmatic verification (not browser unless necessary)

## Load Bundles as Needed

- `database_work/` - Ash patterns, migrations
- `ui_work/` - LiveView, DaisyUI, components
- `data_import/` - Import scripts, idempotency
- `testing/` - Test patterns, precommit
- `tools/` - Dev tools, operations

### Use maestro_tool for reusable scripts, not project-specific tasks

‚ùå **Anti-pattern:** Putting project-specific mix tasks in individual projects instead of the shared tool

**Why:** Makes scripts reusable across all projects. Reduces duplication. Single source of truth for tooling.

### When user says 'learn', extract key patterns from current session interactively

‚ùå **Anti-pattern:** Manually editing guideline files or trying to automate without user confirmation

**Why:** User knows what patterns matter. Interactive extraction ensures we capture the right learnings, not just what the tool guesses.

### Maestro manages the ~/dev/agents directory - guidelines, usage_rules, bundles, and sessions

‚ùå **Anti-pattern:** Treating agents directory as static documentation instead of managed infrastructure

**Why:** Maestro is the orchestrator - it maintains shared knowledge that all projects consume. This includes syncing upstream changes (like Phoenix AGENTS.md), organizing guidelines, and managing the usage_rules structure.

### Maestro orchestrates by preparing task files, not by implementing solutions

‚ùå **Anti-pattern:** Creating implementation guides or doing the project work yourself instead of letting the assigned agent do it

**Why:** Maestro's job is coordination: write TASK.md, current_task.json, build startup.json with role-specific bundles (maestro docs + task-specific guidelines like NEWPROJECT.md). Trust the next agent to research and implement.
source_files.USER_CONTEXT.md:
# User Context

## User Profile

**Name:** Vince
**Shell:** zsh (with git completions and aliases)
**OS:** macOS
**Editor:** VSCodium / Cursor
**Development Directory:** ~/dev/

## Environment

### Communication Style
- Direct and efficient
- Uses conversational aliases (see ALIASES.md)
- Appreciates concise responses
- "Learn" means document for reuse, not just solve

## What Agents Should Know

### You Don't Need
- Interactive prompts (assume yes for standard operations)
- Verbose explanations (be concise)

### You Do Need
- To recognize conversational aliases (hi, bye, ci, learn, wip)

### Communication Preferences
- **Concise:** 1-3 sentences when possible
- **No preamble:** Don't explain what you're about to do, just do it
- **No postamble:** Don't summarize what you just did
- **Show results:** Code changes, file outputs, verification
- **Ask when stuck:** 1-2 attempts, then ask

bootstrap.purpose: Minimal core rules - git workflow, verification, tracking

description: Startup configuration for Maestro AI sessions - all content bundled
philosophy: Load less, reference more. Read what you need when you need it. Everything you need to start is in this file.

readme.content:
# Maestro

Project orchestration and agent coordination hub.

## Project Tasks

### Current: Agent Startup Optimization

**The Problem:** AI agents spend enormous amounts of time, money, and tokens loading all guidelines at session start. We need to solve this by loading only what's needed for specific tasks.

**The Solution:**
- **Maestro** (this project): Reads entire `agents/` directory to have full context for coordinating work
- **Other projects**: Load minimal essential guidelines at startup
- **Task-specific loading**: When we assign a task to another project, Maestro tells them exactly what guidelines they need to read
- **Usage tracking**: Track which guidelines agents actually reference during work to optimize future sessions

**How it works:**
1. Maestro plans tasks for other projects here
2. Maestro writes the task with specific reading requirements to the project's CHANGELOG
3. That project's agent starts up, reads minimal guidelines + task-specific ones
4. Agent logs which guidelines were actually used (server log style)
5. We analyze logs to optimize what to load by default

**Current status:**
- ‚úÖ Maestro reads everything (agents/ directory)
- ‚úÖ Other project startup files created (minimal loading)
- ‚ö†Ô∏è GUIDELINE_USAGE_TRACKER exists but not being used as intended
- üîÑ Need to implement usage logging (agent-oriented, like server logs)
- üîÑ Need to test with other projects loading minimal set

### Completed: CSS Linter Integration

**Branch:** feature/css-linter

**Goal:** Move Tailwind analysis UI from Maestro to css_linter tool, making it reusable across all projects.

**Status:** ‚úÖ Working, needs migration for full functionality

**What was done:**
- Copied TailwindAnalysisLive to css_linter package
- Refactored to be repo-agnostic and mountable from any app
- Added LiveTable dependency to css_linter
- Configured and mounted in Maestro (separate scope to avoid namespace collision)

**Remaining:**
- Run migration for css_class_usage table
- Test UI functionality
- Remove old Maestro-specific analysis files
- Document web UI usage in css_linter

### Access Points

- **Web App**: http://localhost:4004
- **Live Debugger**: http://localhost:4012

## Managing the Agents Directory

Maestro is responsible for managing `~/dev/agents/` - the central repository of shared knowledge for all projects.

**Directory structure:**
- The `agents/` directory is **symlinked into each project** (e.g., `maestro/agents -> ~/dev/agents`)
- This allows all projects to share the same guidelines without duplication
- Changes made in one project's agents directory affect all projects
- The canonical version lives at `~/dev/agents/` and is a git repository

**What Maestro manages:**
- **Guidelines** (`bootstrap/`, `ui_work/`, `database_work/`, etc.) - Core patterns and best practices
- **Usage Rules** (`usage_rules/`) - Package-specific guidelines from dependencies and our forks
- **Bundles** (`bundles/`) - Consolidated guideline sets for efficient loading
- **Sessions** (`sessions/`) - Archived learnings from agent sessions
- **Logs** (`logs/`) - Session tracking data for optimization

**Key responsibilities:**
- Sync upstream changes from frameworks (e.g., Phoenix AGENTS.md ‚Üí `bootstrap/PHOENIX_AGENTS.md`)
- Build and maintain usage_rules bundles using `mix usage_rules.sync`
- Extract learnings from sessions using `mix session.learn`
- Generate concept maps and relationships between guidelines
- Track guideline usage to optimize startup bundles

**Why this matters:** Other projects consume from this directory but Maestro is the orchestrator that maintains it. This ensures all projects have access to current, well-organized knowledge without duplication.

## Orchestration Features

Current features:
- **Project Dashboard**: View status of all projects
- **Real-time Monitoring**: Track which projects are running (ProjectMonitor GenServer checks TCP ports every 10s)
- **Guideline Browser**: Visual tree of all agent guidelines
- **LiveTable Integration**: Uses vintrepid/live_table fork with DaisyUI styling

Planned features:
- **Task Planning**: Create and assign tasks to other projects
- **Usage Analytics**: Track which guidelines are actually referenced
- **Smart Loading**: Recommend minimal guideline set based on task type
- **Multi-Project Commands**: Start/stop multiple projects
- **Log Aggregation**: View logs from all projects
- **Environment Management**: Manage .env files across projects

## Technical Details

### Project Monitoring
- ProjectMonitor GenServer checks TCP ports every 10s
- LiveView updates UI every 5s
- Real-time status indicators (green=running, red=stopped)

### Dashboard
- Uses LiveTable component from vintrepid/live_table fork
- DaisyUI styling with table-pin-rows for fixed headers
- Sortable and searchable project listing

### Guideline Browser
- Visual tree view of entire agents directory
- Helps agents understand available documentation
- Checkbox tracking (UI-only, not persisted)

### Database
- Uses Ash Framework with PostgreSQL
- Ecto for css_linter integration (Ash not compatible with LiveTable)
- Seeds include 6 projects: Ready, Calvin, SanJuan, new_project, Maestro, np

## Development Setup

### Prerequisites

- Elixir 1.18.3
- PostgreSQL running at localhost
- Erlang/OTP 27

### Getting Started

```bash
cd ~/dev/maestro
source .env
mix deps.get
mix ecto.setup
mix phx.server
```

Visit: http://localhost:4004

### Database Commands

```bash
mix ecto.create
mix ecto.migrate
mix ecto.reset
```

## Project Structure

```
lib/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ maestro/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ops/              # Project management
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ maestro_web/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/       # Guideline viewer, etc
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ live/            # Dashboard, project detail
priv/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ repo/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ migrations/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ seeds.exs
```

## Other Projects Tracked

- **Ready**: Web 4000, Debugger 4008
- **new_project**: Web 4001, Debugger 4009
- **Calvin**: Web 4002, Debugger 4010
- **SanJuan**: Web 4003, Debugger 4011
- **Circle**: Web 4015, Debugger 4016

sections: What Was Done - actions taken, key decisions

content.description:
## Goal
Extract UI patterns from Calvin work, document them, and evaluate Chelekom component library for Maestro.

## Context
- Calvin had UI improvements (unclear what exactly)
- Created css_linter (analyzes CSS usage)
- Created ui.compact & ui.add_expandable scripts (transform UI)
- Chelekom documentation exists (CHELEKOM_NOTES.md)
- Need to consolidate UI knowledge

## Questions to Answer
1. What specific UI improvements did we do in Calvin?
2. Are they captured anywhere? Scripts? Docs?
3. Should we use Chelekom components in Maestro?
4. How do Chelekom components compare to current approach?

## Tasks
- [ ] Review Calvin project git history for UI work
- [ ] Check if ui.compact/add_expandable apply Calvin lessons
- [ ] Review CHELEKOM_NOTES.md thoroughly
- [ ] Evaluate Chelekom for Maestro (pros/cons)
- [ ] Document decision and rationale
- [ ] If yes to Chelekom: Create installation/migration plan
- [ ] Extract any missing patterns from Calvin work

## Resources
- ~/dev/agents/docs/chelekom/CHELEKOM_NOTES.md
- ~/dev/forks/css_linter (analysis tool)
- ~/dev/forks/maestro_tool (transformation scripts)
- Calvin project git history

critical_rules: Use Ash for all task updates (never browser manipulation)
Write completion notes BEFORE marking done
Log session: mix bundles.track init maestro <branch> <bundles>

workflow.1_start_session: Read this file (startup.json) - everything bundled here
workflow.4_load_contextual: If task involves another project, read their README. If task type known, load relevant bundle (ui, models, etc). For library patterns, consult USAGE_RULES.md
workflow.5_work: Execute task, logging guideline usage as you go
workflow.6_end_session: mix bundles.track summary && mix session.capacity <used> 200000 && mix startup.build
